column6: Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
column13: Stockland conducts regular analysis of gender pay equity to understand any differences in pay between men and women in its organisation. Stockland's long-term objective is to achieve zero gender pay gap. It can only be achieved by addressing inequalities between men and women, such as the under-representation of women in higher-paid jobs and leadership roles.
column20: Gender pay equity analysis, zero gender pay gap, inequality

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column13: Stockland's second Everyday Respect campaign aimed to increase awareness and understanding of acceptable and unacceptable behaviour, equipping employees to deal with everyday sexism and encouraging them to speak up.
column20: Everyday Respect campaign, awareness, unacceptable behaviour

column4: Freedom of Association and Collective Bargaining
column6: Operations and suppliers in which the right to freedom of association and collective bargaining may be at risk
column13: Stockland's modern slavery risk assessment delved deeper into its corporate, operational, and direct supply chains to understand its potential to influence and mitigate modern slavery risk. Stockland utilised the Social Hotspot Database to determine the likelihood of social risks occurring in different industries and countries.
column20: Modern slavery risk assessment, supply chain, social risk

column6: Operations and suppliers at significant risk for incidents of child labor
column13: Stockland has several core mandatory training programs that all new employees must undertake to comply with its obligations under the Human Rights Policy. All employees are required to refresh this training every 18 months. The training includes modules on equal opportunity in employment, sexual harassment in the workplace and workplace bullying. Stockland also delivers targeted unconscious bias training as required and launches a company-wide online resource for all leaders, guiding inclusive leadership and managing day-to-day issues related to human rights.
column20: Human Rights Policy training, mandatory training, equal opportunity

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column13: In collaboration with the Property Council of Australia (PCA) and industry experts, Stockland developed a property industry modern slavery supplier assessment tool hosted by Informed 365 (I365), which provides a Supplier Assessment Questionnaire. The questionnaire allows suppliers to provide their responses to all clients on the same platform, increasing transparency and efficiency in data sharing.
column20: Supplier Assessment Questionnaire, modern slavery, Property Council of Australia

column6: Security personnel trained in human rights policies or procedures
column13: Stockland continues to offer the online training tool Building Links to engage its suppliers and assist them in understanding and managing risks and labour exploitation in the construction sector. The Anti-Slavery Taskforce administers the Building Links program and aims to educate and increase awareness of modern slavery risks.
column20: Building Links, an online training tool, modern slavery

column6: Incidents of violations involving rights of indigenous peoples
column7: No violations involving indigenous peoples' rights were reported in Stockland's code of conduct breaches or grievances or through the whistleblower channels in FY23.

column6: Operations that have been subject to human rights reviews or impacts assessments
column13: In FY23, Stockland developed its inaugural First Nations Strategy, which aims to embed its commitment to Indigenous engagement and reconciliation into how Stockland operates its business. The strategy is focused on those areas that Stockland can contribute to, including employment, procurement, cultural learning, designing with country and cultural heritage and land management.
column20: First Nations Strategy, Indigenous engagement, procurement

column6: Employee training on human rights policies or procedures
column13: Stockland increased its internal capacity and capability by establishing the Stockland Indigenous Engagement Team, an all-Indigenous team of experts across the country with over 80 years of collective knowledge and experience in Indigenous affairs, community engagement, reconciliation strategies, Indigenous employment and procurement initiatives, as well delivering and implementing cultural awareness and learning programs.
column20: Indigenous Engagement Team, collective knowledge, reconciliation strategy

Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The Stockland CARE Foundation is a charitable trust established to deliver programs and initiatives to improve people's lives in or near Stockland communities. In alignment with its refreshed ESG Strategy and its focus on impact, Stockland is evolving the CARE Foundation's strategy beyond community investment to place-based social innovation and the identification of partnerships that will enable Stockland to deliver on the ESG Strategy. The Foundation will be an enabler and exemplar of social value creation at Stockland.
column20: Stockland CARE Foundation, ESG strategy, community investment

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Through the relationship with Wallumatta (Dharug Ngurra/Country), Her Traditional Custodians, the Dharug people, and the broader Indigenous community, Stockland is working to embed Designing with Country principles into its projects and better understand Country at M_Park in NSW. Stockland considered the Designing with Country principles to be applied to benefit the country, humans, and non-human lives, including Sensing, Hearing, Envisioning, and Caring.
column20: Designing with Country, Wallumatta, Designing with Country

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Stockland's Aura community on the Sunshine Coast is well known for its white roofs or cool roofs policy, which was implemented to reduce the Urban Heat Island Effect. Heat mapping revealed a difference in temperature of 1.5-2 degrees Celsius between Aura and the surrounding suburbs, which contributed to increased comfort levels for the residents. A data-driven scalability framework was established to provide a system of measurement and cost-benefit analysis of cooling mitigation measures and how they could be scaled across Stockland's portfolio. High-performing reduction measures identified as part of the framework included cool roads and cool roofs, increased tree canopy cover and vegetation, orientation-related decisions and green roofs.
column20: Data-driven scalability framework, cool roofs policy, Urban Heat Island Effect

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Stockland's cultural diversity strategy encourages support for cultural participation, access, and the right to express and interpret culture. Stockland's Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP) is a key component that outlines its commitment to deepening the understanding of its shared histories, cultures and achievements. Progress against Stockland's RAP actions is tracked and reported throughout the year, including targets for indigenous employment opportunities and procurement spending. Stockland is committed to progressing the RAP and is deeply aligned with its purpose.
column20: Reconciliation Action Plan, cultural diversity strategy, cultural participation

New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column8: What Stockland Expects from its Suppliers
column13: Stockland is guided by its 'What Stockland Expects from its Suppliers' Policy. Stockland is dedicated to responsible procurement and expects its suppliers and their supply chains to operate in a manner consistent with Stockland's values, objectives, and relevant legislation. The policy states Stockland's expectations that its suppliers and supply chains implement appropriate labour policies across their organisations to eliminate modern slavery.
column20: What Stockland Expects from its Suppliers, Responsible Procurement, supplier

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Given the inherently complex nature of property development, the large number of suppliers involved, and the diverse services, materials and equipment required to deliver large-scale developments, Stockland relies on its project life cycle process for development projects (D-Life). D-Life identifies and incorporates specific gates with critical control points, requiring approval before proceeding to the next phase of the project life cycle, enabling compliance and reducing risk.
column20: D-Life, supplier, life cycle process

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Stockland's human rights issue reviews identified its supply chain as having the highest potential for human rights risk, prompting the need to acknowledge and understand its potential to be directly linked to modern slavery risk through its corporate, operational, and direct supply chain.
column20: Human rights issue review, supply chain, human rights risk

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Stockland has a comprehensive procurement pre-qualification and assessment process to vet its suppliers and contractors from the beginning of an engagement. Tender assessments are weighted to balance cost, time, and capability. For cleaning contractors, tenders are assessed using on-site and historical knowledge regarding appropriate time allowance to complete jobs, eliminating mispriced tenders.
column20: Procurement pre-qualification, tender assessment, time allowance

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Stockland transitioned to a co-delivery model for its modern slavery and human rights contractor assessment program. It involves part of Stockland's program being completed by its personnel to strengthen its ongoing relationships with contractors further and increase its oversight and management of modern slavery controls.
column20: Co-delivery model, modern slavery, human rights

Political contributions
column7: Stockland makes no donations to politicians or political parties at any level of government.

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: Stockland considers customer safety and security critical points in the project life cycle's design, development, and construction stages and throughout group-wide business activities. In the design phase, major projects in Stockland's Commercial Property and Communities businesses undergo design risk reviews to identify and mitigate potential health and safety impacts. Stockland conducts regular inspections across its projects and assets in construction and operations to identify opportunities for improved health and safety systems and process performance.
column20: Design risk review, customer safety, security-critical point

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: Stockland's approach to physical security is supported by its Vehicle Impact Mitigation Guideline. The guideline provides asset-specific security and safety measures to minimise the likelihood and consequence of accidental or malicious incidents caused by motor vehicles.
column20: Vehicle Impact Mitigation Gudeline, physical security, safety measure

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: Monitoring and surveillance systems commonly include closed-circuit television (CCTV) and active security guards. Stockland's Commercial Property assets use monitoring (CCTV and security guards) and emergency management procedures that are regularly reviewed and enhanced. Stockland's Masterplanned Communities and Land Lease Communities generally have different control measures that reflect their risk profiles, such as cameras and emergency notification systems at the Masterplanned Communities sales centres and communications to residents to mitigate common risks, including unauthorised access.
column20: Emergency management procedures, CCTV, surveillance system

column6: Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: Internal reviews and external insurance property and general liability audits are undertaken regularly to measure compliance with operational risk policies and procedures. It includes a review of public safety and emergency response planning at an asset level. Risks identified through the audit program are recorded, monitored, and tracked so that relevant responsible management teams address compliance and identify gaps in a risk-prioritised manner. In addition, Operational Risk audits are undertaken across each asset and active project to measure compliance against Stockland's operational risk management system.
column20: Operational Risk audit, liability audit, operational risk policy
